Introduction

Shigellosis is caused by Shigella species bacteria, a group of gram-negative, facultative intracellular pathogens.  It is characterized by acute diarrhea (with progression to bloody diarrhea), fever, and abdominal cramping.  This highly transmissible disease spreads primarily via the fecal-oral route (eg, contaminated food or water, direct person-to-person contact).  Humans are the only natural reservoir for this infection.  Shigellosis is particularly prevalent in regions with inadequate sanitation or overcrowding and can lead to severe complications such as hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS).

Pathophysiology



Shigella invade the intestinal (primary colonic) epithelium through microfold (M) cells in the mucosa.  The bacteria can spread laterally via actin polymerization, avoiding immune detection (

figure 1
).  Replication within host macrophages results in apoptosis and causes a profound inflammatory response with ulceration of mucosal cells (leading to bloody and mucoid diarrhea).  The Shiga toxin, produced by certain strains (eg, S dysenteriae), inhibits the 60S subunit of ribosomes, halting protein synthesis and leading to cell death.  Failure of protein synthesis causes damage to the enterocytes as well as the renal and vascular endothelium, underlying the systemic complications of shigellosis such as HUS.

Risk factors



  • Poor sanitation:  Living in or traveling to areas with contaminated water (consumption or recreation) or food supplies increases exposure.
  • Age:  Children are at higher risk, likely due to poor hand hygiene, exposure in settings such as day care centers, and immature immune systems.
  • Immunocompromise:  HIV infection, malnutrition, or other immunosuppressive conditions increase the risk for infection, particularly due to low inoculum of bacteria required to cause infection.
  • Close contact:  Due to high transmissibility, institutions such as day care centers, nursing homes, or homeless shelters can see rapid spread of disease.  Close contact with an infected person at home is also a risk factor (eg, an ill sibling).
  • Sexual practices:  Patients who have receptive anal or oral-anal intercourse are at increased risk due to potential direct inoculation from an infected partner.

Pathology



Shigella are nonâ€“lactose fermenting gram-negative bacilli with no hydrogen sulfide production on triple sugar iron agar (

figure 2
).  Macroscopically, the colon of patients with shigellosis exhibits edema, erythema, and ulceration.  Histopathologic findings include mucosal necrosis and dense infiltration of neutrophils in the lamina propria.  Pseudomembrane formation within the colon can be seen, although it is more common in immunocompromised patients (
image 1
).  In severe cases (eg, with development of HUS), signs of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia due to intravascular shearing can be seen (eg, schistocytes on peripheral smear) (
image 2
).

Clinical presentation



The incubation period of shigellosis is typically 1-3 days.  Symptoms vary in severity but may include:



  • Diarrhea:  Initial watery diarrhea progresses to dysentery (stools with blood and mucus).  Small-volume stools reflect infection of the colon, differentiating small intestinal infections, which produce large-volume diarrhea.  Nausea and vomiting are typically absent.
  • Fever:  Fever typically develops a few days after exposure to the bacteria.  It is often associated with fatigue and malaise.
  • Abdominal pain:  The pain is cramping and localized to the lower abdomen.
  • Tenesmus:  Primarily affecting the rectosigmoid colon, tenesmus causes pain with defecation.
  • Seizures:  Up to 10% of children with Shigella infection are affected by seizures, likely due to massive cytokine response (eg, interleukin-1, tumor necrosis factor alpha).

Diagnosis



Confirmation of shigellosis by stool testing may take several days.  Treatment is often initiated based on a presumptive clinical diagnosis.



  • Stool microscopy:  Fecal leukocytes and red blood cells indicate an inflammatory cause of diarrhea.
  • Stool culture:  Culture is the gold standard for identifying Shigella species; susceptibility testing is also clinically indicated due to increasing antibiotic resistance.
  • Blood cultures:  Blood cultures may be positive if bacteremia is present.
  • Molecular methods:  PCR (eg, of stool) allows for rapid and sensitive detection of Shigella and Shiga toxin.

Laboratory/imaging evaluation



  • Basic metabolic panel:  There may be electrolyte derangements (eg, hypokalemia).  In HUS, elevation in blood urea nitrogen and creatinine are seen due to microvascular damage in the kidneys.
  • Complete blood count:  Leukocytosis is often seen.  In cases complicated by HUS, thrombocytopenia is seen.
  • Peripheral blood smear:  In cases of HUS, schistocytes (red blood cell fragments due to mechanical shearing) are seen as a result of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia.
  • Imaging:  Abdominal imaging (eg, CT scan) can be utilized if there is clinical concern for complications such as perforation or toxic megacolon.

Management



The management of shigellosis focuses on supportive care and, in certain cases, antimicrobial therapy:

Supportive care



  • Oral or intravenous rehydration is important to correct dehydration and electrolyte imbalances.
  • Antimotility agents (eg, loperamide) are not recommended due to the risk for a worsened or prolonged disease course.

Antimicrobial therapy



  • Antibiotics are recommended for immunocompromised patients, those with severe cases requiring hospitalization, or those with extraintestinal manifestations.
  • They may be recommended even in patients without significant comorbidity or disease if they pose a public health/transmission risk (eg, food handlers, childcare providers).
  • Common agents include fluoroquinolones (eg, levofloxacin or ciprofloxacin) or azithromycin for outpatient oral treatment.  Carbapenems (eg, ertapenem) may be utilized as intravenous therapy in patients who are immunocompromised or have severe disease.
  • Resistance patterns should guide antibiotic selection, particularly in regions with multidrug-resistant Shigella.

Complications



  • Dehydration:  Severe diarrhea may lead to hypovolemia and electrolyte abnormalities.
  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS):  HUS is particularly associated with Shiga toxinâ€“producing strains (eg, S dysenteriae).  It is characterized by hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and kidney dysfunction due to microvascular damage and microthrombi (

    ).  Schistocytes (fragmented red blood cells) can be seen on peripheral smear.
  • Seizures:  As noted, up to 10% of children are affected by seizures.  This is due to massive cytokine response (eg, IL-1, tumor necrosis factor alpha) and is often associated with fever.
  • Rectal prolapse:  Prolapse is more common in infants and young children, although it is a rare complication overall.
  • Toxic megacolon, obstruction, or perforation:  These are rare complications, but they can cause a significant risk for morbidity and mortality.

Differential diagnosis



Shigellosis must be differentiated from other causes of acute inflammatory diarrhea, particularly those with similar presentations (

figure 3
), (

):



  • Salmonella infections can present with diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain, often linked with consuming undercooked meat/poultry.  High fever with temperature-pulse dissociation and hepatosplenomegaly are seen with typhoidal Salmonella (enteric fever).  These features are not typically seen in Shigella infections.  Stool culture and PCR testing may be utilized to distinguish these conditions.
  • Campylobacter jejuni causes diarrhea (with blood and mucus) and abdominal cramping similar to Shigella.  However, Campylobacter is typically linked with exposure to undercooked poultry, nausea and vomiting are relatively common, and associations include Guillain-BarrÃ© syndrome and pseudoappendicitis (right lower quadrant pain due to ileocecitis).  Stool culture can be utilized to distinguish these conditions.
  • Enterohemorrhagic E coli (EHEC) O157:H7 is a type of Shiga toxinâ€“producing E coli (STEC) that causes bloody diarrhea and carries a risk for HUS.  However, unlike Shigella, fevers are not common in STEC (possibly because STEC toxins are associated with a predominantly local [vs systemic] inflammatory response).  EHEC is also often linked to consumption of undercooked beef or contaminated produce.
  • Yersinia enterocolitica presents with diarrhea, but pharyngitis may be present as a distinguishing symptom.  History of exposure to undercooked pork or unpasteurized milk may also help distinguish from other bacterial infections of the intestines.  Stool studies are positive for Yersinia.
  • Amebiasis (Entamoeba histolytica) is a parasitic infection associated with dysentery and abdominal pain but is linked to travel to resource-limited areas.  The diagnosis of amebiasis relies on trophozoite detection in stool or on serology (if liver abscess is suspected).
  • Gonococcal proctitis can present with mucus and blood in the stool as well as with tenesmus.  In contrast to patients with Shigella infections, diarrhea is not prominent.  Patients with proctitis may be more likely to experience constipation.  Nucleic acid amplification testing from a rectal swab will be positive for Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

Prognosis



Most cases of shigellosis resolve within a week with appropriate supportive care.  Severe complications are rare in otherwise healthy individuals but may lead to significant morbidity in vulnerable populations.  Mortality is low with prompt treatment but may be high if severe complications such as HUS occur.

Summary



Shigellosis is a common cause of bacterial dysentery, characterized by diarrhea (with blood and mucous), fever, and abdominal pain.  It primarily affects young children and individuals in areas with poor sanitation or overcrowding.  Diagnosis is based on clinical features and stool testing, with stool culture as the gold standard.  Management includes rehydration and, when indicated, antibiotics tailored to resistance patterns.  Complications such as dehydration, bacteremia, hemolytic uremic syndrome, seizures, or toxic megacolon can be seen in severe cases.  Although prognosis is generally favorable in uncomplicated cases, increasing antibiotic resistance underscores the need for improved sanitation and judicious use of antibiotics.
